Parto dalla mia personale visione dello stile pixellato. Lo odio ! Ok, ok, cercherò di essere più professionale. Mettiamola così: credo si tratti di uno stile che ormai non ha più ragion d'essere; che esisteva un tempo perchè non c'erano alternative, giacchè i computer di allora avevano una memoria risicata; infine è fastidioso poichè diventa difficilissimo dover cercare gli hotspot in una massa caotica di pixel colorati. Quindi trovo la scelta del pixellato abbastanza ridicola, se si vuole fare l'operazione nostalgia, ci sono tante altre cose che si possono fare. 
Tolto questo, passiamo al resto. Il gioco prende ispirazioni diverse: nelle meccaniche e nelle interfacce da Gabriel Knight, nelle atmosfere e nella trama dalle opere di JJ Abrahms e sono questi due elementi i pilastri che sorreggono l'intera pericolante struttura. Gli enigmi sono buoni, di difficoltà media e con un contorno di indizi per chi può trovarsi in difficoltà. Le atmosfere sono create molto bene grazie a delle musiche accattivanti, personaggi ambigui pieni di misteri da svelare (inclusa la protagonista) e aggiungerei le ambientazioni se non fossero disegnate in pixellato che finisce per ridicolizzarle un po'. La trama l'ho lasciata per ultima perchè mi lascia sconcertato. Tutta la storia si basa su un mistero ma alla fine quel mistero non viene svelato per nulla, non restano nemmeno indizi che possano permettere al giocatore di darsi la sua personale spiegazione; ma la cosa più assurda è che perfino alla protagonista che tanto si è sbattuta per capirci qualcosa, alla fine non importi nulla. C'è quindi il serio rischio che a qualcuno resti l'amaro in bocca.
Concludendo, è un gioco che avrebbe potuto offrire molto e invece si limita ad essere un esercizio di stile da parte degli sviluppatori un po' come quei film bellissimi esteticamente ma vuoti al loro interno. Ciò nonostante potrebbe piacere l'atmosfera surreale che si respira e la storia dietro i personaggi ma di certo non vale la pena spendere 15€ per un gioco con una grafica datata e una trama che che non va da nessuna parte, all'interno di una tipologia di avventura grafica in cui la trama diventa fondamentale.
Non potendo però usare una scala di valori di giudizio o un voto neutro io dico: Lo consiglio CON RISERVA.

Un petit jeu d'aventure qui a tout d'un grand !

A l'heure ou Thimbleweed Park est encencé autant par la presse spécialisée que par les joueurs, il ne faut pas oublier Kathy Rain qui est sorti l'année derniere dans une relative discrétion.

Et pourtant quel jeu agréable et vraiment très prenant !

On y incarne une étudiante fan de Harley qui alors qu'elle se rend à l'enterrement de son grand père, va se retrouver embarquée dans une grande aventure ou se meleront investigations, disparitions et paranormal.

Tout au long de la petite dizaine d'heures que vous prendra l'aventure, vous y croiserez divers personnages et situations très variées et qui participeront à l'atmosphère inquiétante et pleine de mystères et de secrets enfouis. 

L'aspect graphique rend brillament hommage aux jeux d'aventures de la "grande époque" et les dialogues intégralement doublés en anglais sont interprétés avec conviction et implication. C'est un vrai plaisir d'entendre notre protagoniste principale nous faire part de ses nombreuses remarques très cyniques. (Le jeu possède un excellent sous-titrage FR)

Si il n'y qu'un seul point négatif à signaler, hormis le fait qu'on voudrait que l'aventure dure un peu plus longtemps, c'est lorsque nous arrivons dans la dernière ligne droite du jeu (grosso modo la dernière heure environ), j'ai trouvé que la fin de l'histoire s'emballait un peu trop vite et nous assènait diverses situations qui nous laissaient un petit peu dans l'expectative pour la bonne compréhension générale du dénouement final. (Peut-être est-ce juste moi, chacun y trouvera une interprétation facile à comprendre ou non...)

Mais ce n'est qu'un petit détail qui n'entache en rien l'avis très positif que j'ai de ce jeu et le plaisir que j'ai eu à vivre cette aventure résolument un peu plus "mature" que les autres jeux de ce style.


MON AVIS FINAL :


Un excellent point and click indépendant avec une très bonne histoire globale, une héroine très attachante et qui n'a pas sa langue dans sa poche, le tout au service d'un univers et d'une ambiance qui se rapproche de celle de la série Twin Peaks.

Si je devais le comparer à un jeu d'aventure qui m'a marqué, je dirais que ce Kathy Rain ressemble beaucoup au tout premier Gabriel Knight (Tout en ayant un cadre et une enquête sur des sujets bien différents). 

A se procurer sans l'ombre d'une hésitation pour tous les fans des jeux d'aventures old school de la glorieuse époque ! (LucasArt, Sierra et Cie ! )

31050754.review:
Kathy Rain is detective adventure game that deeply homages David Lynch’s work. If it homaged any more you could call it Twin Peaks the game. Inspiration aside, Kathy Rain marries the detective genre and point and click adventure game beautifully with a decent story and 8-bit graphics.

The art is done well, albeit in low resolution graphics. The game has some modern mechanics, but overall the look is quite dated (comparable to Broken Sword). Meanwhile, the voice acting varies between passable and good. Overall, the production quality gets passing marks for an indie development.  Nothing egregious nor outstanding.

The gameplay solid, it is a point and click adventure, but unlike most, there is no inane puzzle logic. Everything was either quite logically or Kathy hints at what she should do next. With that kind of gameplay the detective work shines through nicely. You end up doing interviews, looking for clues and following up on leads.  Puzzles are strewn in, but nothing feels out of place, and themed around unlocking via riddles or codes.  Gameplay is quite excellent for a point and click adventure.

Finally, the story. You will get déjà vu playing this game if you have seen Twin Peaks. Many major elements from Lynch’s work are mirrored here. From the Red Room to the dead girl in the lake, plot points really could not come much closer. To be fair, that’s not a bad thing. Enough is different to call it original, but that does not mean it is not trope ridden. The main character, Kathy, comes off as a bit of a strawman.  Basically, she is the perfect example of a cynical girl from a broken home having made all the wrong choices but having the strength to endure it all anyway. I feel like she’s the best friend from a poorly written RomCom and her temperamental attitude takes a while to get use to as she comes off as rude for very little reason for most of the start of the game. But as it progresses, she chills out and becomes more likeable as her sardonic quips become more sarcastic. Aside from the rough characterization, the story depicts a rural mystery with surreal elements with quite a lot of care.  I won’t get into the details, but this isn’t really a whodunit so much as a “what the heck is going on?” 

If you’re a fan of mysteries, point and click adventures or David Lynch this game might be up your alley. There’s very little to criticize beyond the dated graphics and a lot to like.

Kathy Rain is a good "old" point & click game with a low-res nostalgic look that could make you think this game came straight from the 90s.
And as a matter of fact the story takes place in the 90s: Kathy is studying journalism at college and lives at the dorm with her roommate Eileen and gets a phone call to be informed about her Grandfather's death. Nothing new, but that's the point of reviving a classic, right? For some odd reason there are two different options for examining an item, and even though you don't get much more information then usual from them, I kind of liked the idea as classic P&C just have the same line for every item.

The soundtrack during the game is pleasant and appropirate, even though the title track and the travel track really are the only ones that really stand out.

Riddles are well built, nothing extremely complicated nor easy as a click (except for [spoiler]the scanner that can scan audio tapes, seriously, the last thing I could have thought of was examining a scanner to realize that...[/spoiler]), the best part of the game surely lies in the story that will take you around the town and let you talk with characters... Long and interesting talks. And the story (no spoilers) will really go deep to end up in an unexpected direction.

Definitely a really appreciated work, made with heart and mind, and with this I'm definitely keeping an eye on Clifftop Games. (no, I'm not paid by the publisher nor the developer. I just grew up with games like Monkey Island and Sam & Max)

This game's story is dumb, you guys.

Really dumb.

Look, I grew up on 90s point and click adventure games just like you ([i]in all likelihood, given that you're looking at this game.[/i]) And if you're looking for something that just captures the spirit of the era - look no further! It checks all the boxes, from the font choice to the art style. You'd swear up and down it was made in the same Scumm engine as Full Throttle and Day of The Tentacle. Hell, it even has the same issues with questionable voice acting quality - Kathy herself is generally well played, but the NPCs around her range from serviceable to downright atrocious.

But here's the thing - the story in this game... its [i]bad.[/i] It starts out fine - a young journalist comes back home to attend her grandfather's funeral, then gets caught up in the mystery of his sudden illness. Cool! But... about halfway through... something terrible happens.

The writers give up.

See, they set up a lot of loose threads to handle. And, frankly, loose threads are fun - they make for interesting stories. Forcing characters to deal with the implications of their decisions is at the heart of any good narrative. Buuuut... rather than commit to that, they start hand-waving in a VERY big way. Investigation starts giving way to "it's magic, yo". And, ultimately, every single major plotline is resolved through magical means. And not interesting, well fleshed out magic, either (looking your way, The Longest Journey.) No... just boring, half-thought-out dream visions and spirit quests.

It's deus ex machina on steroids. And what’s worse is it undercuts the core premise: its not Kathy’s investigation skills that solve the day, but instead these mystical forces directly spelling it out for her.

Look, you’re not a ~bad person~ if you like this game. Playing Kathy Rain won’t give you cancer or kill your dog or whatever.

But frankly, other than the obvious nostalgia hooks, this game is actually a lot weaker than many of the 90s games it mimics. The UX is bad. The game is short. The puzzles are generally so brainless that they’ll take you literally seconds to figure out. So all that leaves is the story it tells.

And guys? The story is [i][u]dumb.[/u]

29360452.review:
My opinion is a bit divided on this game.  There were features about it that I did enjoy, but ultimately I'd have to say that the negative aspects outweigh the positive.  For me at least.  I'm in the minority opinion here.  I'll start off with the positive.  I liked that all of the dialogue for the game had voice acting, including Kathy's inner thoughts.  You don't get that in most of these kinds of games, so I'll give the game credit for that.  There will be mixed opinions on the quality of the voice acting, but it was serviceable to me.  

Within the story, I do like that it tackles some very heavy emotional issues.  This includes mental illness, death and loss, and very imperfect family situations.  It's gritty and dark, but very humane.  I just wish the story didn't trail off and get weaker the further it went.  Along with this, I did like some of the characters quite a bit.  Kathy is a bit inconsistent, but she's mostly likeable.  I thought Goober was funny, though kind of tragic the more you learn about him.  The grandmother also isn't purely the sweet, loveable figure (towards Kathy she is, unquestionably).  She shows some anger and distrust, which gave her more range than most games show towards those kinds of characters.  I thought Eileen was kind of weak though - so over the top in her chipperness and having absolutely no sense of privacy or personal boundaries.  That was hard to swallow.

Something else done well is the art and graphics.  I liked the contrast of the pixel art for the majority of the scene, and the use of more detailed art to show facial expressions.  There were only a few varieties in the sprites though, so it didn't have as much nuance as it could have, but it added much more than only the pixel art would have shown on its own.  One thing I thought was odd about the pixel art is that everyone's eyes are set against a black dot instead of white, which makes them all look creepy.  Not sure why that choice was made.

Starting off in the negative, I would say the story could have been better (and there will be spoilers throughout, fair warning).  Starting off I think it's pretty strong.  It builds Kathy's character pretty well (though she's very contradictory in nature - spiteful and angry, a smart ass who's harsh with her words and even actions, like when she won't give a homeless man $10, yet also very soft-hearted in other ways), and develops her family history.  It becomes apparent quite quickly she grew up in a troubled family situation, with her being so estranged from her paternal grandparents, and not so much by choice.  

The first couple of days where you try to figure out the basic details of what happened to your grandfather, who might know essential information, and starting to dig through the surface level events to the darker, hidden truth is quite good.  I'd say the second day especially makes you feel like a detective, as you play different people in order to get the tech. set up you need to further explore the clues you've found so far.  The hints are subtle but straightforward enough (very delicate but important balance), with Kathy giving you enough pointers that you're able to get where you need to go (I'm thinking especially with the voice recording manipulation - that was well laid out).

However, it also becomes clear soon enough that the mystery she's trying to untangle about the possible foul play surrounding her grandfather was supernatural in nature.  Nothing in the trailer or game description suggests this, which I feel is very misleading.  The title especially hints at a strong female character unraveling a bigger plot or conspiracy, not trying to work out a paranormal activity that overshadows events in her life and the town she was raised in.  Plotwise the story comes off less like CSI and more like the X-Files, which isn't what I was expecting or really wanting to be honest.  Those sorts of stories are prevelant enough, especially in hidden object games (the closely related cousin to point and click games).  

I don't want to beat a dead horse, but the more I think about the overall story of this game, the less it all makes sense.  I would summarize it in these few questions.  Who paid for her grandfather's storage unit the last 14 years that he's been in a vegatative state (those things aren't free and your grandmother knows nothing about it at all)?  Is the Red Man a force for evil or not (key characters flat out say so, but if that's the case his actions with other characters don't make sense)?  Is the Old God legitimate, a real thing, and how does that work stacked up against the Christian God (what's the reality of the supernatural for the game - is this a dimensional rift or what)?  Why is it that Kathy Rain was the only character that had the inner strength to handle the descent into the Abyss, especially when earlier interactions show she was probably more troubled than other people likely would be (dozens if not hundreds of people go missing or crazy because they can't handle it, yet she did)?  I also have to wonder a lot about the church and its members, since the pastor is clearly unhinged and sacrifices people regularly, yet plenty of people go there without reservation (the sheriff being one of them).  It's not that the game doesn't answer these questions that bothers me so much as that the game's story isn't internally consistent.

A few other simple details in the game design bothered me as well.  I didn't like how, later in the game, certain areas you've been to before became grayed out, with you unable to go there anymore.  I feel like the point of these types of games is to allow the player to explore everywhere, even if it's the wrong place, until they figure out the next step to take.  However here those options are taken away, without explanation, which was disappointing to me.  It felt restrictive and didn't give a chance for me to wrap up what felt like unfinished business in those areas either.  It also raises the question of why not just gray out the wrong places for me to go all throughout the game if that's going to be done later on anyways?

Another one is how the game telegraphs that you'll do things later on in the game without any need to do so.  One that comes up very early is the mausoleum - it says you can enter it, long before you have any reason to think to do so, which tells the player you will eventually do that.  Another example of that is after you encounter the Red Man you don't ever see Sue again and don't talk to Nathan until far later in the game.  I wanted to talk with him very shortly after the experience, and while pursuing that goal the option to break into their cabin comes up.  There's no reason to do so since they aren't there (and the event where you need to do it isn't triggered until much later), but despite Kathy saying she won't do things needlessly, especially something that drastic, you're able to break in, even though it's entirely pointless.  That seemed out of character and weird for her.  

There are other nitpicks I have, but they aren't worth mentioning at this point.  I would say overall that I'm disappointed by the direction the story took in this game, especially since there are some pretty glaring plot holes and inconsistencies, along with plain unanswered or unexplained aspects to it. [h1]Een goed 'wijs en klik' avonturen spel[/h1]
Kathy Rain is het schoolvoorbeeld van een retro mid jaren negentig 'wijs en klik' spel, maar dan in een modern jasje. Het spel doet sterk denken als klassiekers als Gabriel Knight en Full Throttle, maar met een volledig eigen verhaal en originele puzzels. Veel puzzels zijn gebaseerd op dialogen en andere puzzles bestaan uit het manipuleren van de omgeving op een geloofwaardige manier. Geen schuifpuzzels dus of schermen met 'verborgen voorwerpen'. In Kathy Rain volgen we de lotgevallen van de eigenzinnige Kathy Rain, een tweedejaars studente journalistiek die in de geschiedenis van haar grootvader duikt. Nadat haar kamergenoot haar heeft overtuigd om naar de begrafenis van haar grootvader te gaan, raakt Kathy geïntrigeerd in het verleden van haar grootvader. Na een geheimzinnige gebeurtenis in 1981 (het spel speelt zich af in 1995) is haar grootvader als kasplantje in een rolstoel geëindigd. Kathy was toen een kleuter en werd opgevoed door haar moeder, nadat haar vader hen had verlaten voor een motorbende. Gedurende haar onderzoek komt Kathy niet alleen meer te weten over haar grootvader, maar ook over haar eigen verleden en over wat er tussen haar ouder en grootouders is voorgevallen. Naarmate het verhaal vordert, worden er steeds meer bovennatuurlijke elementen geïntroduceerd.
De puzzels zijn op een goede manier in het spel verwerkt. Veel puzzels zijn dialoog gebaseerd en vereisen dat je met anderen praat en de juiste opties kiest of het juiste voorwerp laat zien. Andere puzzels vereisen het combineren of gebruiken van voorwerpen op een gebruikelijke manier. Voor sommige puzzels moet je een creatieve aanpak kiezen, maar ik ben geen puzzels tegen gekomen die onlogisch waren of waarvoor je ieder scherm minutieus moest uitkammen. In een van de puzzels moet je een opname van een antwoordapparaat bewerken en een nieuwe opname samenstellen. In Gabriel Knight moest je hetzelfde doen, maar werd de opname alleen goedgekeurd als deze woord voor woord klopte. In Kathy Rain controleert het spel of je de juiste woorden hebt geselecteerd en vervolgens past Kathy de opname zelf aan. Iets vergelijkbaars geldt voor het bellen van telefoonnummers. In de jaren negentig moest je in veel spellen elke keer het nummer volledig draaien. In Kathy Rain klik je op de naam die je wil bellen op een lijst op het scherm. Het is deze mix van retro en modern die het spel tot een goed afgewerkt geheel maken.
Kathy Rain is het resultaat van een eenmans studio en dus is het aantal locaties en het aantal personen waar je mee kunt spreken beperkt. Toch voelt het niet aan als een klein spel. Met 6-8 speeluren is het aanzienlijk korter dan Gabriel Knight of Full Throttle, maar die zijn dan ook door een volledig team gemaakt. Alle dialogen zijn gesproken en zo te horen door professionele stemacteurs. Door het interessante verhaal, de goedgeschreven dialogen en de goed in het spel verwerkte puzzels, voelt het onddanks de beperkte omvang toch aan als een volwaardig spel, een hele prestatie.

Nancy Drew grew up, got an edge, and became entangled in a dark local mystery involving the supernatural. That might be enough to convince you to play Kathy Rain, but if it's not, read on.

Kathy Rain is a wonderful graduation for those of us who grew up with HerInteractive's Nancy Drew series. Many of us also had a (perhaps handed down) NES, Atari, or Game Boy, so we've a nostalgic love of pixels. We're also a bit generationally jaded, sharing Kathy's world-weariness and sarcasm. There's a darkness in both the character and the game that feels personally relevant.

Not in that demographic? No problem. Kathy Rain holds appeal for any fan of point and click mysteries. Bonus appeal if you're a fan of the supernatural and slightly macabre, and you like seeing it in pixels. The game is logical in its progression; if you get stuck, just try what you would do in real life. There's no tedious haphazard item combination. Puzzles are clean and feasible. Even with full achievements, you can complete the game in ~5-8 hours, so it's a solid adventure that won't eat all your time. (Great spoiler-free achievement guide[url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=679054771]here[/url].)

Kathy Rain is a satisfying offering in the PnC mystery/adventure genre, comfortable to play with a nice nostalgic aesthetic. You couldn't ask for much more, but the game gives it anyway: an intriguing story and a surprising depth of themes and character. Satisfying, and highly recommended.

Kathy Rain is a story driven game done in a point-and-click style of gameplay. 

Pro's: 

1. Pixel styled graphics make the game extremely easy to run and a very small download size.

2. A strong female protagonist with depth, a dark history and a ton of guilt. 

3. Great voice acting and immersive sound tracks.

4. Surprisingly diverse interactivity with environments that can lead to interesting responses.

5. Mostly simple puzzles and riddles so progress is easy enough for those new to point-and-click games

Con's:

1. The slow beginning gives a false sense of pacing for the rest of the game

2. Some puzzles did seem a little obscure and required a sudden burst of 'thinking outside of the box'.

3. Without spoilers; the end of the game seemed to reach out a little from what starts as a solid and down to earth detective's tale.

4. After tying up all logical ends the game seems to bait at a sequel or at the very least ends on a rather predictable note.

Pro/Con??? : There were no credits at the end... Personally I like to pay respects to those who make such an entertaining game as Kathy Rain.

Conclusion: 

Kathy Rain is a promising first game for the developers and for the most part stays true to what it promises. I'd highly recommend it to anyone who wants to break into the point-and-click field or any one who is looking for a fairly good, story driven experience. For the 7-9 hours it takes to play this game I would certainly put it on my 'to play' list if you're at the very least intruiged.

Che magnifico titolo! Sono fresco fresco di finale, ma quella che ho appena giocato è sicuramente una delle migliori avventure indie degli ultimi anni. 
La storia di sicuro vi terrà incollati per un 6-7 ore, e vi porterà ad impersonare Kathy Rain, giovane giornalista che tornata nella piccola Conwell Springs per assistere al funerale del proprio nonno, inizierà ad investigare sul misterioso passato di quest'ultimo. Non voglio scendere nei dettagli, ma il gioco è chiaramente un omaggio a serie cult come Twin Peaks o la prima stagione di True Detective.
I personaggi sono memorabili, ognuno con una propria personalità ben definita e un doppiaggio assolutamente ottimo che vi farà percepire i personaggi realmente vivi.
Trattandosi di un punta&clicca, saranno presenti numerosi enigmi nel corso dell'avventura, tutti abbastanza affrontabili con un po' di sana logica (a parte qualcuno verso la fine del gioco), e con una buona conoscenza della lingua inglese; si, perché Kathy Rain è completamente in inglese al momento, e di traduzione in italiano nemmeno l'ombra.

Gli scenari proposti non sono moltissimi, a causa del ridotto team di lavoro che conta solamente una persona, Joel Staaf Hästö, che si presenta col nome di facciata di Clifftop Games. La grafica va a richiamare le avventure grafiche dei primi anni '90 (anzi a dire il vero anche troppo visto che all'epoca erano ben più definite) e gira ad una risoluzione di 320x240 in 4:3, cosa davvero frustrante, ma capisco anche che così facendo si vadano a mascherare certezze e difetti di questa piccola produzione.

Anche se con qualche incertezza, rimane un ottimo titolo, che va a guadagnarsi ben 4 stelle su 5. Ben fatto Joel.

Dobra przygodówka. Dobra fabuła. Dobre zagadki. Dobry tribute dla Gabriela Knighta.

Uwodzi swoim podejściem do fabuły. Początek jest dosyć łagodny, ale z czasem gra zaczyna poruszać takie tematy jak: depresja, szaleństwo, samobójstwo, nieuleczalna choroba, samotność, ilozacja, porzucenie, narkotyki, picie i świadome dążenie do samodestrukcji. Ale spokojnie, są też i lżejsze momenty.

Minus? Być może fabuła za bardzo idzie w niecodzienność. Wiem, brzmi dziwnie. Spróbuję to wytłumaczyć. Gdy gra się skończyła byłem usatysfakcjonowany, każdy główny wątek zakończono. Ale, biorąc pod uwagę wcześniejsze zwroty fabularne, miałem nadzieję na to, że zakończą się dziwniej, bardziej szalenie.

Do tego sporo zwrotów fabularnych. Sporo też nawiązań do filmów i seriali z lat 90. Szczególnie do filmów Davida Lyncha - Twin Peaks, Zagubiona Autostrada, Dzikość Serca. Widać inspirację Lovecraftem, Lśnieniem, a nawet serią Silent Hill.

Zagadki są dobrze zaprojektowane. Nie było momentu, w którym nie miałem jasnego celu. Kilka razy musiałem fizycznie w notatniku zapiski robić, aby dojść do tego celu, bo niektóre są dość trudne, ale zawsze wiedziałem do czego dążę. Jest sporo typowego "użyj przedmiot na przedmiocie" i dużo wyciągania informacji z rozmóców, ale gra dodaje tu i ówdzie jednorazowe ciekawostki, które powodują, że rozgrywka nie jest nudna.

Gra też ciągnie sporo mechanik z serii Gabriel Knight. Niektóre sceny są więcej niż inspirowane pierwszą częścią GK (jak wszystkie sceny z babcią i sprawdzaniem co dziadek zostawił na poddaszu).

Podłożone głosy są zazwyczaj fantastyczne, a w najgorszym razie - bardzo dobre. Jest jedna konretna scena, którą jakby przeanalizować nie jest dobra pod kątem mechaniki czy narracji (nie wiem czy jest potrzebna) ale aktorzy tak dobrze ją odgrywają, że byłem cały czas zaangażowany w to co się dzieje.

Muzyka jest świetna. Pomaga podkreślić charakter każdej lokacji. Niektórych kawałków chętnie posłuchałbym poza grą.

28171730.review:
[h1]Story[/h1]
Als Kathy vom Tod ihres Großvaters erfährt entschließt sie zurück in ihren Heimatort zu fahren, den sie seit Jahren gemieden hatte. Doch bereits die Beerdigung hinterlässt bei Kathy ein merkwürdiges Gefühl. Also erst einmal eine Zigarette rauchen, aufs Motorrad springen und auf zur Großmutter. Dort angekommen erfahren wir, dass der Großvater nach einem mysteriösen Unfall in den 80ern nicht mehr der gleiche war…  
 
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Kathy Rain ist ein klassisches Point&Click Adventure mit allem was dazu gehört. Einem Inventar, der Möglichkeit Dinge zu kombinieren, verschiedene Dialogwege zu gehen und kleinen sowie größeren Puzzles. 
Dennoch ist Kathy Rain keine Kopie der Genre-Größen. Das liegt vor allem an der Hauptperson, die alles andere als auf den Mund gefallen ist. Häufig treffen wir das „böse F-Wort“ und zynische und sarkastische Antworten gehören zur Selbstverständlichkeit. Die Orte des Geschehens wechseln wir auf unserem pinken Motorrad und wenn uns danach ist, können wir auch mal eine Zigarette rauchen. Was zunächst aufgesetzt klingt, funktioniert jedoch tatsächlich recht gut und Kathy wächst dem Spieler schnell ans Herz.

[h1]Grafik und Sound[/h1]
Die Grafik ist ebenso wie das Gameplay „klassisch“ im positiven Sinn. Wer bis heute nicht genug von Pixelart hat, wird auch hier Gefallen finden. Die Szenen sind liebevoll mit kleinen Details ausgeschmückt und alles wirkt sinnvoll auf die Zeit abgestimmt. So finden wir etwa ein Pulp Fiction Poster über unserem Bett (und ein Titanic-Poster über dem der Mitbewohnerin), spielen mal in einem Windows 3.1 Verschnitt und geben Nummern in ein Tastentelefon ein.
Dazu gibt es einen angenehmen Soundtrack und eine wirklich gute und authentische (englische) Sprachausgabe. 

[h1]Steuerung[/h1]
Auch hier sei der Verweis auf frühere Point&Click Adventure erlaubt. Ohne Maus geht gar nichts, extra Einstellungen gibt es nicht und eine Controllerunterstützung sucht man vergebens. Maximal die Leertaste kann hilfreich sein um Objekte zu finden, mit denen man Interagieren kann.

[h1]Schwierigkeit[/h1]
Die Puzzles sind allesamt logisch aufgebaut und lediglich an 2-3 Stellen kam ich ins Stocken. Die Rätsel spielen dabei vor allem mit der Sprache, mathematische oder physische Rätsel gibt es nicht. Ein Hilfesystem wie man es aus moderneren Adventurespielen kennt gibt es nicht jedoch werden Orte, an denen es wirklich nichts mehr zu erledigen gibt ausgegraut. Die Leertaste kann helfen ein „Pixelhunting“ zu verhindern.

[h1]Spielzeit[/h1]
Wie bereits erwähnt, sind die Rätsel nicht so schwer, dass man an manchen Stellen stundenlang festhängt. Je nachdem wie erfahren man im Genre ist, kann dies jedoch trotzdem immer mal wieder passieren. Spieler, denen Point and Clicks jedoch bekannt sind, werden die Story jedoch nach etwa 4h beenden können. Der Wiederspielwert ist dabei leider gering, da die Story sehr gradlinig ist und es keine alternativen Enden gibt. Achivementsammler sollten also ggf. vorher einmal schauen, wie die Errungenschaften heißen (dies sollte als Tipp bereits reichen).

[h1]Fazit[/h1]
Kathy Rain ist ein kleines aber feines Adventurespiel, welches von der Grafik und der Steuerung sehr an alte Lukas-Arts Juwelen erinnert. Dazu kommt eine spannende Geschichte und sympathische Charaktere.
Einzig der nichtvorhandene Wiederspielwert kann hier als Kritik angeführt werden. Weiß man einmal, wie es ausgeht besteht kein Grund das Spiel schnell noch einmal zu spielen (nach einigen Jahren kann man es aber sicher noch einmal raus kramen).

I was about 60 seconds into playing 'Kathy Rain', just past the opening cutscene when I first got control of the titular protagonist, I  moused around and clicked on a poster: "That's from 'The Thing' one of my favourite horror movies." explained Kathy. In that moment I knew that me and Kathy were going to get along just fine, and I also knew that this was one game that I'd be seeing all the way through. 5 hours or so later (accounting for some idle time) here I am telling you to take the trip too.

'Kathy Rain' does nearly everything right. Kathy herself is a joy to work with and one of the best video game protagonists I've ever spent time with. The game is as much about her as it is about the mystery she uncovers, and while none of the supporting cast can quite match the engagement that she induces that's because she's a high-water mark. The puzzles are clever, but designed to be logically solvable, and while I'm not a braniac genius (although I do have the whole stable of Lucasarts and Sierra titles under my belt) nothing stumped me for more than 30 seconds and I was never tempted to reach for a walkthrough. I'd say the difficulty is slightly on the easy side of the genre average although good design contributes a lot to that ease; there are no moments where it feels like the game is jerking you around with 'game logic' and Kathy is always willing to offer subtle direction. 

The story won't be to everyone's taste, and honestly the direction that the plot took was... interesting. I was expecting 'Veronica Mars' but this is more 'Twin Peaks' (and darker than that by the end). This is by no means a bad thing but it's definitely not the game you want to use to introduce a pre-teen to the world of adventure gaming. 

You're not a pre-teen though, right? You should totally play this. It rocks.

For instance, I really enjoyed Primordia, Technobablyon and other Wadjet Eye Games. Don't get me wrong, Kathy Rain is going good so far, but there are inherent issues with the engine, it's not designed to accommodate things like Alt Tab, which is very annoying when I'm working and gaming at the same time. Often it would freeze the image on my screen and I'd have to restart my computer. Despite running an old engine, they need a way of accommodating modern ways of traversing applications, otherwise it becomes an annoyance.

The game itself is decent, with a fair story arc. The character is slightly unbelievable for a 90's goth girl? Seems like she has Emo streaks and then she drives a motor bike? Highly confusing. Despite that the character element and puzzles were fun and very reasonable. There was no major issues in figuring out clues or piecing things together, had to think about some but they did have a steady logical flow.

The settings are decent, but for the most part they feel a little claustrophobic. Often the emphasis of a scene is designed around the interaction of you and one character or one specific tasked object. This can be fine in Point Clicks but if over used and not given a grander context it begins to drag. 

I felt like they could've used points from games like The Longest Journey, and Broken Sword, Broken Age, where they give you nice large environments instead of narrow and claustrophobic settings. This might change as the game goes on but the pattern seems rather set.

The side characters are slightly uninteresting, bordering annoying. I felt like I cared very little for my roommate, my grandmother or anyone else that I really interacted with.

KATHY RAIN is a gem of adventure, mystery and deduction that holds a deep story and a wealth of depth as you progress through each difficult day.

As Kathy, a rebelious young woman, returns to her home to lay her grandfather to rest, she slowly uncovers secrets to her family's secrets, her grandfather's demise, and her own fragile psyche.  Aboard her trusty chopper, locations are introduced, new clues emerge, and Kathy delves deeper into the mystery of what happened to her family.  

It's all rather pedestrian if it wasn't done so damn well.  Kathy's interactions with her grandmother, a dubious religious organization, a drunken ex-thespian, a wealth of flowers and a red man of questionable origin lead to often bizarre and oddball elements that will lead one to Kathy's ultimate end.  

While the typical point and click elements are in play, there is not much that doesn't yield a result that will undoubtedly be added to Kathy's notebook and available for further exploration later on.  There are a number of backtracks, but none are deal breakers, as Kathy's hearty chopper bounces one from location to location in very short order.  That said, there are times where the Steam community's walkthru is almost a must have; one may find themselves at a crossroads of where to go.  I could not have finished had it not been for the walkthrough to relieve hours of tedium trying to push through to the next proper location.  

There is nothing within KATHY RAIN that would not preclude me from granting it a high recommendation.  The cool 90's graphics and local, great vocal work, and eventful story are all to be heralded among a drab redux of Myst clones or storyless puzzle adventures.  KATHY RAIN has a story to tell, and it is recommended that you lend an ear...

A fully voice-acted adventure game set in the 1990s that looks like it was made in the 1990s, in terms of graphics and much of the gameplay. I managed to complete it without looking up any hints or walkthroughs, though there were definitely a few times that I had some issues solving puzzles here and there. One plus, however, is that pretty much all of the puzzles where you use an item on a person or a thing make sense, which is more than I can say for some puzzles in Deponia and other adventure games both newer and older. 

The graphical style is very neat, the voice-acting is well done, and you have an investigation notepad you update with new things you can ask people, scratching out old notes you've fully covered and have all the info on. You can zoom from one area to another on your motorcycle, with different areas opening up the further you get into the game, and when you've fully finished an area, it's unavailable on your area selection screen (which was good in my opinion, or else any time I got stuck, I would have wandered back to those areas fruitlessly).

What I could not quite get into, beyond the initial purpose of the investigation, was the story itself. As soon as a character spoke to my character, I was like "Yep, that person's probably evil," and the character was evil as a plot twist later on. Kathy is likable in terms of her humor and her nice appearance in design. She's sort of like a friendlier Jessica Jones (sans abilities), though some of her past and her dream sequences were a little off-putting and strange. What's worse, the game features a supernatural element that comes into play a fair bit in,  and it just didn't quite click with me. Supernatural stuff is great, but I just couldn't get into this game's form of it, and it's incredibly relevant to the plot at the end of the game. Right before the credits rolled, I was thinking to myself "This is actually the end, isn't it?" and it has a tacky "Kathy Rain will return" sort of message not-so-subtly voiced by a main character, as though setting up the intent for sequels.

Would I play a sequel? Probably, if I got it super cheap, and though I did enjoy much of my time with the game and appreciate its design, the story and the supernatural element of it, especially, which did not appeal to me, left me dissatisfied with my experience and a bit somber. Granted, it's nothing like coming out of the Mass Effect 3 ending when unprepared for it! Though I do not recommend this game, keep in mind that I am incredibly choosy with what I will or won't recommend, and I would not recommend a game where the story is seems like it should be a huge motivating factor, but said story's elements rubs me the wrong way.

26641816.review:
Sem palavras para descrever o quanto este adventure game merece ser jogado, não só por fãs de adventures mas também por aqueles que amam uma história bem escrita.

 [i]Kathy Rain[/i] me pegou realmente de surpresa, pois mesmo eu acreditando que o jogo tinha grande potencial (diante dos trailers e imagens que sempre me remetiam aos games da série [i]Blackwell[/i]), eu não esperava tamanha qualidade em - sem brincadeira alguma - todos os sentidos. Fazia tempo mesmo que eu não seguia tão intrigado através de um roteiro e, melhor, sem reclamar do final (pois geralmente ao depararmos com certos tipos de trama o "alerta" já desponta para um possível final capenga ou vem o medo daquelas pontas soltas só para poder "pescar" uma sequência).

 Para o primeiro jogo do Clifftop Games, eu diria que foi um marco. Não há palavra que o descreva melhor. E para uma melhor garantia de qualidade ainda teve o suporte do próprio Dave Gilbert (Wadjet Eye; e que criou a série [i]Blackwell[/i], diga-se de passagem) na direção de dublagem, o que só fez com que tudo ficasse ainda mais incrível. Diante disso vale a observação de que [i]Kathy Rain[/i] pode ser considerado até um sucessor espiritual da série [i]Blackwell[/i], mas não pelos personagens ou roteiro, mas sim pela dinâmica dos mesmos e o terreno considerado "sobrenatural" também.

 Falando um pouco da história do jogo em si sem entrar em detalhes comprometedores, posso dizer que Kathy é uma protagonista extremamente carismática (mesmo podendo ser considerada indiferente e hardcore em certos aspectos) e contará com a ajuda de sua colega de quarto da universidade - Eileen (outra personagem carismática, mesmo com a pegada religiosa que a envolve, o que a torna bem interessante também), além de outra gama de personagens envolventes que surgirão para ajudar ou atrapalhar a nossa árdua jornada investigativa. Investigação esta que certamente não pode ser considerada comum e, adianto logo, nunca é o que parece ser. O mistério envolve todo o jogo do início ao fim, diante de uma trama adulta e fascinante. Adulta, pois o jogo não pega leve em diversos temas considerados tabus e utiliza uma linguagem que vai do leve ao pesado sem aviso prévio.

 Outra coisa que é bastante válida ressaltar é a atmosfera de estranheza que esse jogo emana, do início ao fim. Não é comum para jogos pixelados conseguir esse feito, ainda mais com histórias que se utilizam de contextos do cotidiano e dramas familiares, porém em [i]Kathy Rain[/i] isso é tudo plano de fundo mesmo. A trama central é fascinante e tudo somente é revelado mesmo no final. Mas o legal mesmo é nunca saber para onde estamos seguindo, pois sempre aparece algo novo e o que pensávamos ser realmente importante depois se revela algo bem menor. E não é por menos que o jogo possui esse clima weird/nonsense, pois aqui temos inspirações da série televisiva [i]Twin Peaks[/i], [i]Arquivo X[/i], e surge até espaço para os amantes do horror cósmico em inúmeros momentos que não direi quais. Aqui estamos a abrir uma maravilhosa caixa de surpresas aterradoras.

 Os puzzles apresentados em [i]Kathy Rain[/i] são bastante intuitivos, apesar de não pegarem leve em certos momentos. Fazia tempo também que não lidava com enigmas tão criativos e interessantes. Em resumo: é melhor você ter um caderninho e uma caneta de lado só pra garantir. Nada demais, porém também nada de menos. A trilha sonora é muito boa e também nos remete aos clássicos pixelados que tanto conhecemos, mas se utiliza também de toques mais dramáticos em certos momentos, ou seja, não é só a dublagem que é fantástica. Como eu já mencionei, o conjunto da obra aqui é realmente incrível em todos os sentidos.

 Se o jogo terá uma sequência, ainda não sabemos, apesar de um final "meio" em aberto e da confirmação de seu criador acerca do desejo de conceber uma - talvez - nova série. Mas este primeiro título por si só já consegue ser grandioso e, se não alcançar boas vendas neste mercado bizarro de games atual (já que vender bem seria o principal fator para uma possível sequência existir), será apenas uma triste consequência do momento. Eu mesmo estou na torcida por novos títulos, pois quero muito ver a Kathy em ação novamente e tenho certeza de que a personagem ainda tem muito chão para percorrer.

 A jornada com Kathy e sua motoca está mais do que recomendada. Preparem-se para uma grandiosa aventura, não irão se arrepender.

26551012.review:
Some time ago there was once an adventure series by the developer Wadjet Eye called The Blackwell series. In it a young woman with the ability to see spirits and her ghostly companion solve supernatural cases. That series ended in 2014 and for me, since then there's been a small hole which this series used to fill. It wasn't the best but the writing was decent, the puzzles thoughtful and you could really get into the story.

Fast forward 2 years and here's Kathy Rain. Albeit a completely different personality and game from Blackwell but made in the same engine and a little reminiscent of a game that I felt was great. Now while comparing the two isn't entirely fair I think it's on par with the level of story, puzzles and dialogue that the aforementioned had. 

Kathy has quite a rebellious personality. She's got piercings, dyed hair and an attitude to match. Did I mention she also drives a motorcycle? She's got that air of angsty, feminist chic going for her and she smokes. But at the same time our badass rebel has a soft spot for family which is what brings her back to a small town from her childhood to find out about her grandfather's death. 

There's a fair bit of detective work going on as you uncover the truth about your grandfather's past. You'll got to various locations. Meet many of the locals and get your hands dirty. And the great thing about Kathy is she's quite intelligent and resourceful. I also found myself enjoying her dialogue as in most situations she's giving a snarky remark not only to people in her way but also when I do silly things like try to light a little boy in the cemetery on fire or screw the local sheriff. The writing is definitely not boring or predictable. But it also doesn't take itself too seriously.

The music and graphics also fit well with to complement Kathy's personality and general setting. There's semi-diverse locations that complement the somber mood and the music from the opening to the guitar track looping during your motorcycle transitions is great. 

As for the puzzle aspect of the game there's some really well thought out and executed puzzles. They blend well into the story and doesn't feel like they're added to give the player something to do. Meaning you'll have to think a bit. Not too hard or long but consider things when you're chatting with people that there might be a clue somewhere not explicitly mentioned in your notes. You might even need 2-3 different items to figure out a puzzle but rest assured that it's never really complicated. In all I have been enjoying this game and think that most adventure fans won't be disappointed.

26462440.review:
My friend gave me this game as he didn't want it as part of a humble bundle, so I decided to try it.

It exceeded every expectation I could possibly have.

The pixel-graphics are implemented in such a way that makes it clear as to what is what, and there's no pixel-hunting so to speak. Holding the spacebar highlights all objects in the room that you can examine in case you think you missed something. I wasn't expecting voice acting, but every single line of dialogue and narrative is fully voiced, and spectacularly so; every voice fits the character's personality and setting. The puzzles and trials that you come across require a proper level of critical thinking; no information is explicitly hidden from you, and there is never any guessing involved if you've searched and discovered every detail available.

What started as me giving some point-and-click adventure a try ended with a wild ride of puzzle solving, investigating and getting confused at all the plot that's being thrown in my face. Even after the story, I still feel a bit confused at some story elements that will most likely be made clear on a second playthrough (in which I'll get all the hidden achievements). 

In conclusion, I feel this game is severely underappreciated, and definitely qualifies as a hidden gem. I would very strongly recommend it to anyone who enjoys point-and-click adventures or a good mystery story narrative.

26090584.review:
Any Gabriel Knight fans out there?

It was many years ago when I first played the first part of the Gabriel Knight series,  "Sins of the fathers", which already had a few years under its belt back then. And it was wonderful. This adventure had a great story, believable characters, a realistic setting (at least in the beginning), great (sometimes quite hard) puzzles, and a writing with some well balanced mixture of excitement, mystery and humour to it. GK1 immediately became my favourite adventure, and it stayed that way ever since.

But what does this have to do with Kathy Rain? Why would I bring this up?

Because KR almost immediately created the same feelings I had when I played GK1 back then. Almost from the title screen it felt like playing a Gabriel Knight game. But this was not only subjective - there are objective resemblances between those two games. And it was not just the visuals:
- Both KR and GK1 have a great mixture of humour and mystery, without the humour spoiling the mystery
- In both games the main character has a sidekick that does some part of the research
- Both main characters are sarcastic, somewhat messy writers riding mororcycles
- The family history plays a major role in both stories
- Both games play roughly at the same time (GK1: 1993; KR: 1995)
- Both games share a large set of common settings (like a church, a police station, a graveyard, a bar, [spoiler]and the scene in the mausoleum[/spoiler] ...)
- Both games pretty much start off with the main character visiting his/her grandmother :)

So... is KR a rip-off?

No, definitely not. While the resemblances may be uncanny, KR develops its own dark story that occasionally makes you laugh, and other times gives you the creeps, and stays strong until the [spoiler](semi open, yet satisfying)[/spoiler] end. The puzzles can be quite challenging, but not too difficult and shouldn't get you stuck. And if you pay attention, you most probably will always know generally what your current tasks are and how you might complete them.

So basically: Kathy Rain is a great adventure. I would really love to see a second part, and it was wonderful to play something I would call a well done hommage to my favourite adventure of all time :)

25390381.review:
I struggled to get into this one. I adore the Blackwell series and other recent adeventure game throwbacks like Technobabylon and Primordia, but Kathy Rain never manages to reach those dramatic heights. Uninspired puzzles, a tedious middle plot, redundant mechanics, and a Lynchian dream of an endgame all rank Kathy Rain well below titles published over two decades ago.

Ultimately, it's good enough for most genre fans, but there are far better titles out there; however, as a diehard genre fan, I truly hope we see more of Kathy because she deserves a second bout to prove her mettle. I had hoped to see a lot more from what I still believe a very clever character.

To its credit, Kathy Rain pays homage to the classics of Sierra and Lucasarts, even dropping a few references here and there (and an unmistakable Twin Peaks nod to boot). Applying the vocal direction of Wadjet Eye's own Dave Gilbert elevates the game's dialogue with a strong dramatic presence, and the background art is beyond reproach-- especially for a one-man effort. 

There's a lot that point 'n click veterans will find almost all-too-familiar, though: a Gabriel Knight-style notepad for dialogue; a GK3 tape recorder puzzle; a Monkey Island 2 poem/song puzzle in which the verses correspond to a combination; and, of course, "USE"ing every item on everything just like in [insert adventure game here].  It's a game aplomb with such similarities -- similarities so frequent that you may find yourself saying "I've played this game before."  Unfortunately, the borrowing tactic harms Kathy Rain's novelty, and its untethered plot cannot rescue it. 

Truthfully it would be easy to forgive Kathy Rain if the story didn't let me down. The plot's midsection drags as Kathy spends her time gathering new dialogue topics and trying them out on different characters. I admit that at one point during a particularly uninteresting dialogue, I Shift+Tab'd to Imgur and forgot I was playing the game. 

The endgame leaves many questions to be answered in a LOST-Season-4 kind of way instead of a "When is Stranger Things 2 coming out?" kind of way.

If you don't mind 
-an occasionally dull pace 
-an ayahuasca-bender-inspired ending 
-"puzzles" that rarely ask more than using the right item on the right hotspot (and the few puzzles that do ask more are as challenging as applying the only clue available to the problem)

If you've already played everything else like it, Kathy Rain could be a fine way to spend a few hours.  

If you haven't already played everything else like it, there are a lot of games from two decades ago that are considerably better.

Nesse jogo ambientado na década de '90, você é Kathy Rain, uma estudante durona de jornalismo, que por motivos desconhecidos a fez se rebelar e se distanciar de sua família. Logo no início, você recebe a triste notícia de que seu avô Joseph Rain faleceu, causado por circunstâncias misteriosas que aconteceram em '81. Isto obriga Kathy a ressucitar os fantasmas do passado, e voltar a sua antiga cidade de Conwell Springs para investigar o que está por trás disso.

É um jogo em 2D baseado em point & click, onde vc terá que encontrar pistas, entrevistar os personagens, e resolver os quebra-cabeças. Você vai bater a cabeça para resolver alguns desafios, mas que ao contrário de muitos jogos de detetive, as resoluções são lógicas. A história foi muito bem trabalhada, com um excelente enredo, dublagem em inglês, e trilha sonora. Contudo, não é disponibilizado a legenda em PT-BR, isto significa que se você não compreender textos em inglês, vai dificultar em muito a sua jogabilidade.  Outro contra também é o tempo de duração do jogo, que é muito curto em comparação ao preço cobrado atualmente (R$ 28.00). 

Os gráficos me fazem lembrar das séries Blackwell, e Broken Sword. E se você gostou desses jogos, com certeza irá  Kathy Rain, que tem tudo para se tornar uma franquia de sucesso.

24466762.review:
[i]Kathy Rain[/i] is the type of game that didn’t have to do much to make me want to play it. It’s a point and click game where you play as sassy Kathy Rain trying to investigate the mysterious circumstances surrounding your grandfather’s death. It’s a point and click detective game with a female lead plus retro pixel graphics; on the surface, it seemed like a no-brainer to me. However, upon delving into the game itself I found myself a bit conflicted. Everything about the game is top notch, from visuals to voice acting. The gameplay is smooth as are the controls, it’s the story that lumbers. Depending on a player’s taste, it will be either hit or miss.

I admit when I jumped into this I was eager to play a detective game, working along with Kathy to figure out clues and solve the mysteries. The first half of the game does indeed invoke this tone. You’re in control of Kathy Rain, a journalism major who has a bit of an attitude problem. Despite being a college student, Kathy doesn’t seem to ever go to class, instead opting for being lazy and partying so she has ample time to be a detective on the side. She learns from her roommate, who is the complete opposite to Kathy personality-wise, that her grandfather has passed. Kathy becomes determined to figure out what happened to her grandfather, finding clues to his past as a war veteran as well as the shady history of the town he lived in. With a quick wit and a sharp tongue, we help our hero investigate the situation, finding out that it extends even farther than just dear old granddad all while learning more about Kathy’s troubled upbringing and family issues.

And then things got weird. While I had a suspicion things would take a supernatural twist, I was hoping that they wouldn’t, but they do. Around halfway through the game it becomes clear that this isn’t just a simple detective story, there is something other-worldly happening. I won’t spoil exactly what it is, however I couldn’t even if I wanted to. The ending of the game left me very confused to the point where I have more questions than answers. Between Kathy having weird dreams and talking to ghosts, the game tries to squeeze in character development by having her overcome inner demons that had been holding her back. I commend the story wanting to do this, however I personally didn’t feel the need for the supernatural aspect to do this. The final chapter of the game unfortunately feels rushed because of it, trying to tie up the loose ends of the plot with her grandfather and the creepy town while also giving Kathy her epiphany. While the game seemed to be trying to end in a way satisfying for players, it also left itself open for sequels. 

Story aside, the game itself is very simple. It’s a point and click adventure game so all you need is a mouse to play, though there are a couple of moments where you need to type something in with your keyboard but it’s not a major gameplay aspect. Using your mouse, you control where Kathy goes and what she does, clicking on objects and people to interact with them. You have an inventory system where useful and important items are collected for later use. You can inspect items in your inventory, like to read a newspaper clipping, or combine certain items to either make a new item or effect another item, like using Kathy’s lighter on a Bible in the church. The game has a few puzzles but nothing very complicated and usually Kathy will tell you enough details to figure things out. The only issue I had was that Kathy herself moves rather slowly when she walks, you also can’t double click a door to instantly go through it so you’re forced to wait for Kathy to walk everywhere. 

The game is beautiful, I adored the graphic style and the choice to go with pixel artwork. It’s very simple yet done very well, lovely shading work and the character animations all seem very natural. Each character also has a portrait as well, since it might be hard to see the details of their faces on their character models due to the pixels. The backgrounds are rich, fitting well with the dreary tone of the game. There is also full voice acting and it’s done very well. Kathy has a witty line for almost everything so feel free to click away at items in the game. Every character you interact with has a voice and plenty to say making it easier to immerse yourself in the game. The music also helps with this, the soundtrack is perfectly fitting to the gritty backdrop of the small backwater town. 

This is a game that packs a lot of punch in a small package, while on the surface it may seem like just another point and click game using simple pixel graphics, [i]Kathy Rain[/i] proves itself to be the total package. The writing is amazing, Kathy is an engaging character full of humor and common sense and while I may not have found the story to be perfect, I enjoyed it none the less. The truth is, there could have been flying dogs from Mars that came and took over the town, Kathy herself is such a great main character I would play anyway. She carries this game on her shoulders as she rides down the highway on her pink motorcycle. While the price tag may seem a tad high, you won’t be disappointed if you add this to your library. It’s a fun experience, a well made game and also Steam trading cards and achievements. I hope that this title is only the first in many more games starring Ms. Rain.

23943506.review:
Kathy Rain, subtitled “A Detective Is Born”, is a skillfully modernized update of the classic LucasArts/Sierra-style point-and-click adventure game genre, developed by indie studio Clifftop Games and published by Raw Fury. Aside from a couple of text entry screens, the entire game is controlled via the mouse. Your inventory lives in a handy backpack at the bottom of the screen, and naturally includes valuables like your notebook, taser, smokes, and your favorite lighter. The cursor lights up whenever you pass it over an object or character you can interact with, so you can say goodbye to the old, frustrating hunt-the-pixel puzzles of the past. The puzzles range from “braindead easy” to “somewhat frustrating,” but in the end, they mostly make sense.

There's no way to die here, either – which, while it may take away from the tension a bit, is welcome in a genre notorious for killing characters off for really, really stupid reasons. If you're a fan of the genre, this game will bring you back – while alleviating many of the frustrations that traditionally come with the package. If you're new to the genre, it's a great place to start.

Story and Flow
The year is 1995. Kathy Rain, the titular heroine, is headed back to her old hometown after finding out that her beloved grandfather has suddenly passed away. Once she arrives, of course, she finds out that some strange things have been going on. In the end, she has to face her own demons, even as she digs up those in her grandfather's past.

Is the recalcitrant town sheriff in on some dirty little secrets, or is he just lazy? Is the pushy town priest just desperate for parishioners, or is he more than he seems? Is the crabby lady who lives outside of town really five seconds away from filling you full of lead, or is she just jonesing for a sweet, sweet cancer stick between her lips? Is the mysterious, wealthy industrialist the Big Bad with his fingers in all the local intrigue, or is he just some guy? Play the game and find out.

Controls
Kathy Rain uses the mouse and the left mouse button, along with a couple of very brief text-entry sections, but that's it. Simple and straightforward. Click on a location to go there, click an item (in the world or in your bag) or NPC to interact with or examine them. Choose “Combine” to light up a smoke, drop a cassette into a tape player (remember those, boys and girls?), and the like. Your character will automatically keep track of important conversation points and phone numbers in her notebook. When traveling between areas on your custom chopper, just click the destination and Kathy will ride there on her own. The connection to Full Throttle (which is getting an HD remaster one of these days) is very much in play.

Graphics and Sound
100% all-natural pixels, love 'em or leave 'em. Highly-detailed areas that all contribute to the look and feel of the game's odd little world. You may need to play with the graphics settings a bit to make it easier on the eyes. Right-click the game's list entry in Steam (or CTRL-double click) to access the config utility. Set the graphics filter as high as it will go; if the game refuses to run, drop it down a notch, one at a time, until you get one that your card is happy with (e.g.: screenshots in this article were taken at 1080p, 4X nearest-neighbor filter setting). If you can't stand to stare at pixels, this may not be the game for you.

A free demo is available, though, so give that a shot; it's a good way to assess whether you'll like the visual and aural styles or not. And speaking of aural style, he game’s subtle, effective soundtrack works perfectly with the just-creepy-enough setting, and the voice acting is really good too.
[Eric Kei]

Summary
Kathy Rain features a well-thought out, coherent story, with some superb voice acting that complements the clever writing. Fun bonus: Most of the achievements are for silly things that are unimportant to the plot – e.g. finding a victim for your secondhand smoke, messing with a teddy bear, or even something as simple as idling too long on a screen without doing anything productive. This is a worthy title, and an excellent modernization of the classic point-and-click adventure. I'm looking forward to more from this studio in the future.

Previously published on dlh.net -- Eric_Kei

I loved this game. I was weaned on the early Sierra and Lucasarts adventures a a kid in the 80s, and stuck with that genre until it petered out in the 90s (with some notable exceptions). The recent adventure game revival has been exciting for me in theory, but none of them have really engaged me like some of the games I cut my teeth on once did (granted, as a kid, it was easier to capture my attention than it is now). This game was a masterpiece of writing, art design and voice acting. It wasn't tough, in fact I played it through in one (six hour) sitting. But those hours passed quickly because I was so taken with the story and the characters. There are none of the absurdly difficult combine-every-item-you-have-in-every-possible-order style puzzles, and the puzzles you will face are generally easy (barring one insanely obtuse, but thematically appropriate, one toward the end), but this is a good thing. That is to say the puzzles won't make you pull your hair out and get sick of the game for a week, only to come back to it later and repeat the process.

I think this succeeds so well because it is a game for adults, and given its setting in the 90s, probably for people who lived through that period (ie. former adventure game addicts like myself). There are 'adult themes' and colorful usage of swear words, etc. Even though it's a fairly quick game (I finished it in 6  hours, as I mentioned) it's absolutely worth the $15 price point, and I hope a lot of people buy this so more games of this caliber, within this style, will continue to be made.

Enjoyed it far more than any of the other new, flashier and 'prettier' adventure games. This one provides a memorable thematic experience that will stick with you the way the Colonel's Bequest or Space Quest III (to name a couple) once did. I have intentionally not said anything about the plot, because it's better to come into this game with an open mind, not knowing what to expect next. A+.

I received a key when the game was in closed alpha for testing purposes, so i am one of the early testers. But i plan to buy and give away a key a soon i get some money together because i want to support the dev.

Kathy Rain is a point and click adventure game made with the AGS (Adventure Game Studio) engine. The game mechanics have it's own particularities but it is the similar to other game of this genre. You can think about, look and combine items in your inventory, and you also have a notebook where the important clues are wrote down, you will be able to use these to work out the next course of action and also as conversation topics.

The history unfolds in the great 90's, leaded by a independent girl that studies journalism. She learns about the dead of her grandfather a decides to pay the visit she hesitated doing for many years. Her rebellious and bold spirit will make her get involved in an old strange case and help her investigate using methods that will lead her further than any cop could do when the case was open. It will be a travel to the past.

I honestly love everything about this game, the art and the setting is perfect, the characters are compelling and some of them lovable, the voice acting is superb, the story makes you want to keep playing and want more, the puzzles offer a very decent challenge, not very hard if you are used to this kind of games but not extremely easy either. Playing with all that 20 year old junk was a blast and made me feel nostalgic.

I really hope the dev gets enough support, i can see enough similarities with blackwell here to see it could be a successful series if it's given a chance. The detective is born but she needs to grown, this game is screaming for a sequel.

23147034.review:
--- Mild spoilers regarding base story content ---

Difficult one to review. There really needs to be a midpoint grade on Steam. But, I can't quite go as far as definitively "not recommending" Kathy Rain.

Whether or not it's worth playing is a matter of interpretation. There's been a real lack of old-school P+C adventure games for a while now, and this will scratch an itch, but have a luke warm after taste. If time is precious and you're looking for quality in the realms of the Broken Sword games, though, you certainly won't find it here.

Pros -

Nice retro art style. The pixelation may just be a tad too far, but it works for the most part.

Full voice acting - really well done too.

Mostly logical path progression. None of the bizarre and nonsensical methods of furthering the story with certain puzzles found in games of its ilk are found here.

Cons - 

The story as a whole is very frail and quite slipshod. It's no surprise that references to Jacob's Ladder and other psychological related themes are found here. The problem is the game never really builds the house with which to explore the psycho-babble that presents itself toward the end of the game. Very minor, one-shot flashbacks are the sole source of story-engineering in relation to the main character, and it all comes across as gibberish that you won't care to analyze, unlike, say, a Silent Hill game, where there is a lot more to delve into. A cardinal sin of story telling is to unleash these elements long after the second act has passed. You change the genre and nature of your story at that point, and you have clearly no grasp of your plot, and neither does your audience.

The puzzles range from the incredibly simple to the incredibly simple but vague. Because of the small game areas it's never too hard to guess what actions you need to progress the story. And the puzzles never provide any real brains, except from a few downright nonsensical ones that involve partial riddle-solving that most likely seemed a good idea to the writer at the time. All the difficulty is kind of snuffed out when you can just randomly enter solutions with little recourse, though.


All in all, Kathy Rain has some things going for it. The main character runs the show well. The plot for the first 2 acts has intrigue. However, the creator either lost track of the story he wanted to tell, or just didn't realize how half baked the execution of the final act was.

23020289.review:
Ostatnio twórcy gier często wracają do klimatu lat 90., głównie stosując styl graficzny, który dziś często nazywamy „pikselowym”. Miłośnicy tego stylu na pewno zainteresują się najnowszą przygodówką od Clifftop Games/Raw Fury Games, której akcja dzieje się w 1995 roku – „Kathy Rain”.

„Kathy Rain” opowiada historię upartej studentki z detektywistycznym zacięciem, miłośniczki motocykli, która po kilkunastu latach wraca do rodzinnego miasteczka. Bohaterka rozpoczyna śledztwo w sprawie miejscowej tajemnicy i dziedzictwa swego niedawno zmarłego dziadka. Gdy podąża zostawionymi przez niego wskazówkami, pojawia się coraz więcej pytań... Czego tak naprawdę szukał Joseph Rain tamtej nocy, tak wiele lat temu? Co zmieniło go w cień człowieka, którym się stał, i przykuło do wózka inwalidzkiego? Co młoda artystka, popełniając samobójstwo, wzięła ze sobą do grobu? Dlaczego tak wiele osób w Conwell Springs wariuje? Powrót do rodzinnej miejscowości sprawia, że Kathy poznaje nie tylko tajemnice dziadka, ale też odbywa podróż w głąb własnej duszy i rozprawia się z trudną przeszłością.

To właśnie fabuła jest największą zaletą gry. Poznajemy ją stopniowo, badając kolejne tropy, odkrywamy tajemnice poszczególnych miejsc i osób, docieramy po nitce do kłębka. Historia staje się coraz bardziej zagmatwana, a gracz coraz bardziej chce poznać rozwiązanie zagadki. Czy jednak do końca je poznaje? Myślę, że nie będzie to spoilerem, jeśli powiem, że najprawdopodobniej rozwiązanie to każdy będzie musiał sobie dopowiedzieć sam. Trudno powiedzieć, czy jest to bardziej wadą, czy zaletą produkcji, jedno jest pewne – zostawia furtkę do ewentualnej kontynuacji, która będzie pewnie miała miejsce, jeśli gra odniesie sukces.

Jeśli chodzi o zagadki, w „Kathy Rain” zdecydowanie dominują te przedmiotowe. Są one jednak dość zróżnicowane, a pojawiające się co jakiś czas łamigłówki słowne skutecznie urozmaicają rozgrywkę. Nie są może one szczególnie wymagające i nie pochłoną nas na długie godziny, ale zmuszą do głębszego zastanowienia, a ich rozwiązanie da nam dużą satysfakcję, gdyż odkryjemy kolejny element układanki. Będzie też błądzenie po lesie, otwieranie sejfu, kombinowanie z komputerem, dźwiękiem i obrazem, więc na nudę nie można narzekać.

Twórcy zadbali także o efekty pogody – na cmentarzu mogą powitać nas promienie słońca lub strugi deszczu. Ciekawy także, choć nie innowacyjny, jest system dialogów oparty na notatniku – tematy do rozmowy zmieniają się w nim, gdy zdobywamy nowe informacje.


Na szczególną, moim zdaniem, uwagę, zasługuje udźwiękowienie, zarówno muzyka, jak i nagrania głosów postaci, nad którymi pieczę sprawował znany z Wadjet Eye Games Dave Gilbert. Trzeba przyznać, że warstwa dźwiękowa znakomicie oddaje klimat rozgrywających się wydarzeń, a słowa wypowiadane przez bohaterów pozwalają nam doskonale wczuć się w historię.

Mimo wszystkich plusów gry w pewnym momencie miałam wrażenie, że potencjał historii nie został do końca wykorzystany, a całość poszła w pewnym momencie w kierunku, który nie jest mi bliski. Ale może to tylko moje odczucia?

„Kathy Rain” to produkcja zdecydowanie różniąca się od przygodówek, w które dotychczas grałam. Mimo odniesienia do przeszłości, czyli lat 90., wniosła w gatunek nieco powiewu świeżości. Fabuła, choć nie do końca spójna klimatycznie, naprawdę wciąga na przyzwoite 8 godzin. Moja ocena 8+/10.


Zalety:
- wciągająca historia
- charakterna główna bohaterka
- ciekawe, zróżnicowane zagadki
- ścieżka dźwiękowa
- głosy postaci
- przyzwoita długość
- efekty pogody
- system dialogów

Wady:
- dla niektórych może to być grafika (nie dla mnie)
- nieco mało zagadek
- nie do końca spójna klimatycznie fabuła

P.S. Chciałabym bardzo podziękować twórcom za możliwość udziału w beta-testach oraz zapewnienie, że jeśli gra odniesie sukces, jest szansa na wspólne prace nad polską wersją :)

23013652.review:
This game's 90s heritage goes much deeper than a 4:3 window and 16-bit sprites. Its storyline invokes the 90s as well, with magical mental illness and a Very Special Episode plotline tossed in for pure shock value. Like the television fantasy dramas it draws inspiration from it also promises more than it ever delivers on, wrapping up in a mundane, though not unsatisfying, ending.

That said, the above is what makes the difference between a reccommendation and an enthusiastic reccommendation. Whatever you go into Kathy Rain looking for you're probably going to find it. I forgot to turn off the voice acting when I started (an instinct learned from Blackwell games) and the experience was much the richer for it. I don't know if the developer has the desire to attempt more in their next game, but I'd trust them to achieve it.
